Outfits, tools, summons ‚Äî a psyche prepared for the journey.

What Will You Carry?

Every great hero faces the same questions:
What outfit will you wear?
What power will you wield?
Who will walk beside you?

Carl Jung described individuation as three key encounters:

  • Integrating the Persona ‚Üí Making outfits naturally yours.
  • Assimilating the Shadow ‚Üí Befriending what we once denied.
  • Encountering the Anima/Animus ‚Üí Reconciling the inner Other, finding balance.

In RE:equip, these aren‚Äôt abstract ideas ‚Äî
they become your outfit, weapons, and companions.
The gear you choose shapes the journey you take.


üëó Persona as Outfits

The Persona is your cosmic wardrobe ‚Äî the outfits you choose to navigate life‚Äôs scenes and express your inner Self.

  • Vibes shape how you move and connect.
  • Perks enhance your strengths.
  • Enchantments add personal flair.
  • Integrating the Persona ‚Üí Making outfits naturally yours.


‚öîÔ∏è Shadow as Weapons & Artifacts

The Shadow is what we reject, deny, or suppress.
In RE:equip, these appear as weapons, artifacts, or accessories lying dormant in the arsenal.

  • A sword feared, yet powerful.
  • A cursed relic that tempts.
  • A hidden strength, long forgotten.

Assimilating the Shadow means befriending what once was denied, learning to wield it responsibly.


üêâ Anima/Animus as Summons & Companions

The Anima/Animus is the inner Other ‚Äî bridging qualities we resist yet long for.
Here it becomes a summoned ally, mythical creature, or mentor figure.

  • A guide whose wisdom feels foreign.
  • A creature that challenges and protects.
  • A companion that expands your horizon.

Encountering the Anima/Animus means reconciling with this Other, finding balance in its presence.


üéΩ The Wardrobe of the Psyche

To RE:equip is to step into awareness.
Every armor piece, weapon, and summon is part of you.
Equipping is not escape ‚Äî it is integration.


‚ÄúBefore you can equip, you must know who you are equipping.‚Äù

Your first step is not here.
It begins in What Are You? ‚Äî
discover your base traits before choosing your gear.

    ‚Üí An autobiographical account where Jung frames individuation as a lifelong journey.

    ‚Üí On archetypal roles and cognitive functions as tools for navigating life situations ‚Äî supports the ‚Äúre-equip‚Äù metaphor.

    ‚Üí Maps cognitive functions to brain activity, showing how different mental ‚Äútools‚Äù can be flexibly accessed, aligning with the re-equip concept.
